body: Good point, I'll add some doco.
Added
I think that is ok to merge. Frankly this part of the code cries for removal of code duplication in my opinion, but that is unrelated to the issue

Agreed, and there's also the usages of declared "spreadresult" variables that should be replaced with temporary variables. Thanks for reviewing.

Closing this manually as I forgot to amend my commit message.

Thanks! :+1: 

I'm a big proponent of removing unused/unnecessary code whenever possible.

Hi John,

thanks for the pull request. :)

What exactly are the breaking changes? That some incorrect numbers are not silently parsed to a number?

Hi Pascal, 

Yes, one change would be that invalid numbers integers will now fail on parse instead of being parsed to some value (`1a` == `59`).

Second change is that invalid decimal values will now fail on parse instead of on access.  This change was already in place for extra decimal places (GROOVY-7344) so this just looks for the other cases which are probably not very likely (extra e/E or -/+) but thought should be added for completeness.  Prior to this change parse would be successful but these would throw exceptions on access since they are lazily evaluated as BigDecimals.

I think the changes for the INDEX_OVERLAY parser definitely make sense, I'm a little less sure about LAX.  I guess the argument could be made that for LAX failing on access would be better than failing on parse.

Thanks for the info. :)

Any idea how other JSON parsers handle the LAX parsing?

Thanks for the pull request,

could you please also create a Jira issue to track this?

Thanks!
Sure, I have created Jira: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7675

Good question, I'm not sure how the other parsing libraries handle invalid numbers in their relaxed modes.  I'll try to do some quick testing of the relaxed parsing in some libraries like Jackson and Gson in the next couple of days and will report back.
Thanks!
I guess this ready to merge?

Merged. Thanks! :+1: 

Sorry for taking so long.
The only other question I had was on `FileOutputTool`'s use of BOM.  The change I made was to preserve existing behavior, so I guess should be OK -- just wasn't sure why it was done that way.
@antoaravinth I can do the final clean up myself, but could you please squash the commits? My git skills are not sufficient to squash or even cherry-pick your changes. Thanks!
@PascalSchumacher Sure. Will make the changes of what Paulk as suggested.
I did some very primitive testing and posted my results on the JIRA ticket.
:+1: Everything seemed to be in order to me, tests passed.
Thanks! :+1:
I'm closing this, as the solution does not seem optional. See discussion at: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7074
@blackdrag @melix Does this look ok?
Thanks!
I'm closing the PR, as my new fix for the other test case seems to actually fix both at the same time _and_ is much, much simpler. I need a bit more time to make sure it really checks out.
Thanks! :+1:

As suggested by @melix (on a [previous version](https://github.com/fpavageau/incubator-groovy/commit/0f9fca72cefc9372ea9c3b33eef5b80f3cf7585f#commitcomment-14663466) of the commit I overwrote with a force push), the test case continues to implement `StaticCompilationTestSupport` to make sure it not only passes the static type checks but also compiles statically.
Closing for now. Will potentially revisit post 2.5.
Thanks! :+1:

Just wanted to note that [GROOVY-3976](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-3976) is an open JIRA related to this.  FWIW, I kind of agree with the reporter and would be surprised if many rely on the current behavior of `with` and would be more in favor of a breaking change the next major release than a new yet similiar method.  If it's a new method though, I like `tap` over `doto`.
+1, as you a committer now, you can merge it yourself :)
looks good - I did just try merging it but it looks like some permissions for repo authorisation on the new repo are still pending
If CI says it is good I can give my +1
Does the CI trigger for pull requests?
It used to, but doesn't look like it has since the repo name changed.  I emailed dev list to see if someone can fix.
I don't think the current failure https://builds.apache.org/job/Groovy%20Github%20PRs/103/console is related to my changes
I had the CI do a rebuild and it's green now.
Great! Look forward to it being merged.

Well I don't do ruby, so I have no opinion on the naming; if ruby is the source to look for names, I happily change it to `tap`.  But I am totally against changing `with`. I rarely use `with` without return, but I use it.
@blackdrag @melix What do you think, is this ready to merge?
Thanks for the PR, it's a great improvement.

Thanks for the fix. :)

Could you please create JIRA issues for any fixes/enhancements? Thanks!
Issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7706
Issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7707
Issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7708
Thanks! :+1:
Merged, thanks!  Just waiting for the asfgit bot to bring over the changes to the github mirror.
Merged, thanks!
Merged, thanks!
Thanks! :+1:

Gave it some more thought and I agree that LAX should probably be forgiving and treat invalid numbers as a string.  Any feedback on it would be most welcomed.

Also, I think this qualifies as a bugfix and I misspoke when I said it contains breaking changes.
Merged, thanks for taking a look.

> Gave it some more thought and I agree that LAX should probably be forgiving and treat invalid >numbers as a string. Any feedback on it would be most welcomed.

I'm not JSON expert, but I'm fine with this.

> Also, I think this qualifies as a bugfix and I misspoke when I said it contains breaking changes.

I agree. I think it's fine to merge into the 2_4_X branch. :)

I think the method signature change is ok. But I miss a test case for GROOVY-7420. As for the change itself... Not sure I feel too happy about diverging so much from the method resolution algorithm we use at runtime.  The distance calculation was supposed to catch the cases you have fixed here. Also with the advantage not to have to select the method multiple times. On the other hand I think the change will work without causing too much divergence. So all in all I am ok with the change... once tests have been added

I see your point. I can have a second look to see if I can find a way to plug into the parameters/arguments distance calculation to bias against boxing/unboxing by adding a penalty. It did not seem possible the first time, and I didn't really want to impact the other callers of the modified methods (which is why the original method is overloaded with another one adding the `mode` parameter, and calls it with the same mode as before).

Regarding the test cases, I'm not sure what test you feel is missing. There was [already one](https://github.com/fpavageau/groovy/commit/3583d6d95d664dcfc91402ec324905cf731cd1bd#diff-f6d8ec081f0cf2fcc6dfe44644e336ac) with a `@NotYetImplemented` annotation which is now removed, completed to test both primitive and object calls, and I also [added another test](https://github.com/fpavageau/groovy/blob/3583d6d95d664dcfc91402ec324905cf731cd1bd/src/test/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/sc/bugs/Groovy7420Bug.groovy#L43) to catch a failure I had while running the complete "clean test" build. Do you want more tests to cover the other branches of the method resolution (the varargs cases), maybe also test what happens when the argument is of an narrower primitive type, like `int`? I'll be happy to add some more.

adding a penalty is what the runtime algorithm does. But I really let you decide. I find it more important having someone how is looking at those sometimes very difficult code parts and fixes some things, than to get the perfect solution.  As for the tests, I was actually not seeing that part before, because I looked only at the big file sorry.So I take the part about missing tests back. 

In total I think the change can be merged now

You know what? Based on your comment, I've revisited the parameters/arguments calculation (I've spent more time since that PR in the vicinity, so I'm getting to know it better) and I actually have a one liner fix now which passes the complete "clean test" build.

The distance calculation _did_ try to catch the case I fixed, except it only penalized the unboxing case instead of both boxing and unboxing.

So please, don't merge yet, I'll push the revised fix later.

OK, I've pushed this much nicer and simpler fix, thanks @blackdrag for the prod.

Now if the JVM wouldn't crash when trying to build the PR in Jenkins... :)

the patch looks much better now ;) As for Jenkins... this actually looks like a JVM bug to me. I have seen this kind of error before. I cannot explain why your code triggers it at all. Memory corruption usually may not even tied to the place it happens. And I bet you cannot reproduce the crash locally either. A little change somewhere could be enough to avoid the problem... maybe you want to write an additional test (you could try all primitives for example) and see if that helps

Well, no luck with a new push adding an extra assertion to the test.

All the builds after [127](https://builds.apache.org/job/Groovy%20Github%20PRs/127/consoleFull) have failed (127 did a fresh install of the JDK and Gradle), and they fail right when the JVM starts since there are no Gradle logs at all, contrary to what can be [seen in 127](https://builds.apache.org/job/Groovy%20Github%20PRs/127/consoleFull#gradle-task-0). The container/VM/slave is probably running short on memory and can't properly start the JVM.

In general what I don't like so much is having a having method call or complex expression in a return statement. That makes debugging much more difficult than needed in my eyes. Same for the cases in which you go through a list of checks, then I won`t let the last check just return using an expression. There are multiple cases like those in this pull request. What I mean is that we can do all those changes, but frankly I don't think that most of them really improve the code quality or readability of the code. The loop changes for example and the one generics change are fine. But making return statements more complex.... don't really like that I must say. The cases of local variables before branches and them having a value set, that is then also set in all cases of the branches... that change is ok too for me

In the end it is more a matter of taste

I have no problem removing the changes on the return statements, it's indeed more a matter of taste and personal workflow for debugging (I don't mind stepping inside methods, but that's me), and I certainly don't want to upset other people's workflows.

don't worry about upsetting my workflow ;) If you have new code that does this, no problem. For existing code... well, I would prefer to keep the status quo in that case and do such changes really only if it is more than just a matter of taste ;)
+1 after a CI build
I force-pushed a new version of the same commit, which passed this time. Somebody's fixed Jenkins :).
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks!
Merged the commits! Thanks! :+1:

Build failed because build-server ran out of space `stderr: /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/Groovy Github PRs/.git: No space left on device`, that's unrelated for sure. ;)

PR looks good as far as I can tell. What do you think @blackdrag @melix @shils ?
I've force-pushed to trigger a new build, since the problem of the full disk seems to have been resolved.

Thanks Pascal.

For the record, I'm still working on finding a test proving the fix in what is now 197472c, but haven't had enough time until today. I should have more time on Monday.
Thanks. I will look fixing this in a gradle fork.
Merged, thanks for reviewing.

As requested by @melix in his [comment](https://github.com/fpavageau/groovy/commit/3522575a375b1beca9a893c801efbfda23fde0c5#commitcomment-15101645), I added an explicit test for the array case, even if it was already covered by the tests in `ArraysAndCollectionsSTCTest`.

a couple of comments:
(1) The PhantomReference: I think you are right, the code as it is makes no sense, instead it should maybe use a WeakReference... but looking more at it, I think that check is actually not needed and recentThreadMapRef should be removed and keep only the else block of that if condition. I don't think we really do need that kind of optimization at that point, especially with those questionable semantics
(2) As for finalizeReference vs finalizeRef. That is in fact a good find.
(3) Because of the sensitive nature of things here it would be actually good to have those 3 changes (method rename, change to recentThreadMapRef, weakly reference the class) as separate issue, which we can test in isolation then, to know what change will help and what not.

> (1) The PhantomReference:

I will look more closely at that threalocal local map and submit a separate PR.  At the very least I do think the else and PhantomReference should be removed.

> (2) As for finalizeReference vs finalizeRef.

I have submitted a separate PR #220 for the finalizeReference changes

> (3) Because of the sensitive nature of things here it would be actually good to have those 3 changes (method rename, change to recentThreadMapRef, weakly reference the class) as separate issue

If the method renames look good I will rebase this PR and will send in another for the local map.
could you also test against 7646? Since this fixes a problem in the managed map I would expect this change to really fix the issue

> At the very least I do think the else and PhantomReference should be removed.

Funny, that we see this different... you want to remove the PhantomReference, I want to remove the whole cache aspect of the reference. The result is to get the ThreadLocal every time in my case and not try to get the map directly, in case the current thread and the referenced thread are the same. 

Anyway if the thread is referenced, it must not be a strong reference. That's why WeakReference seems to be the next best to me, if we don't remove the whole logic. I mean current logic is to more or less ignore that map reference and go through the ThreadLocal.
Thanks! :+1:

https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/5c8d97b2cade37a8d4c7c21ecb94d6d35e9e15a8 is the commit. I forgot to amend the commit, so that the pull request is automatically closed. Could you please close the pull request manually? (I can not do, because this is a read only repo.)
Sure, thanks for merging.

I don't see the purpose of the ThreadLocal and LocalMap at all.  It seems to just proxy through to the `globalClassValue` and I don't ever see it getting set with any values.  So while you say remove the whole cache I am thinking remove the whole ThreadLocal and LocalMap altogether.  But it's 2am here so maybe a fresh look in the morning will change my mind.
Well, I haven't been able to create a test that would fail without the fix, because it always fails because of other generics-related bugs anyway :smile:. So I've tackled those instead.

I re-tested 7646 with these changes only and still get an OOME.  A heap dump shows 12k class loaders and they all seem to be rooted via `ClassInfo.klazz`.

If I set `-Dgroovy.use.classvalue=true` then I do not get the OOME.  But that is also true using 2.4.5 with classvalue enabled.

Submitted PR #222 to address the `PhantomReference/ThreadLocalMap` issue.  I could not figure out what the use of a threadlocal cache would be other than maybe to eliminate/reduce lock contention when accessing the global cache.  However, I think it would introduce several potential problems such as another potential to hold refs to class/classinfo and possibly causing problems in thread pool environments.

As it stands I don't think the current implementation is working as a local cache so rather than address the PhantomReference and its use in the ThreadLocal subclass it seemed like removal was the way to go.

One possible use of the local cache that I could think of would be to eliminate/reduce lock contention when accessing the global cache. However, I think it would introduce several potential problems such as another potential to hold refs to class/classinfo and possibly causing problems in thread pool environments.

As it stands I don't think the current implementation is working as a local cache so rather than address the PhantomReference and its use in the ThreadLocal subclass it seemed like removal was the way to go.

This change bothers me since changing the `klazz` to be a weak reference means it could disappear any time during the ClassInfo's lifetime.  Since the lazy refs that access the `klazz` are softly held, the `klazz` should probably be at least a soft reference.

Found a few more issues around `finalizeReference` so added a few more commits.  Ran into the stackoverflow issue (commit 6d68c21) in testing PR #219 against GROOVY-7646.

I re-tested 7646 with the updated changeset and still get OOME.
That was more than I asked for, but still +1 ;)

I too would like to see if the other changes fix the memory leak already and then skip the weak reference change. In theory you will need the class to access the ClassInfo, thus the class cannot have been collected in that case. That is if you want to do anything useful with the ClassInfo. Of course it could still happen if you do not use the class to get the ClassInfo object... and while rare, we may introduce null exceptions in parts of the code, that is not aware of it, plus triggering this in only rare cases
I just added an extra test for the simple unbounded wildcard case: `T extends List<?>`, which uses the `return true` statement I added in `GenericsType.GenericsTypeMatcher.matches()`.
Thanks! :+1:

I tested 7683 and 7646 with the combined changes from PR's #219 / #220 / #222 but without the WeakReference for `ClassInfo.klazz` (i.e., with a hard ref) and still see the leak in 7683 and the OOME in 7646.  

I also test with SoftReferences for both `ClassInfo.klazz` and the `GroovyClassValuePreJava7` map and it also works as does using a WeakReference.  Though I would need to do some more checking with the SoftRef.

I do think a WeakReference is correct in this case, just not sure what cases may possibly ever result in an NPE and what if any handling should be done for it if any.
Thanks! :+1:
